verification_notes: The map \(\omega(p,q)=\det[p;q;c;d]\) is correctly alternating and bilinear in \((p,q)\), since determinant is multilinear in rows and changes sign when swapping the first two rows. The rank-2 conclusion is correct only when \(c,d\) are linearly independent (equivalently \(c\wedge d\neq 0\)). Under that assumption, the radical is \(\{u:\omega(u,v)=0\ \forall v\}=\mathrm{span}\{c,d\}\), so nullity is 2 and rank is 2 on \(\mathbb R^4\). If \(c,d\) are dependent, then \(\omega\equiv 0\) and rank is 0.

verification_notes: The identity is correct in form: if the rank-1 matrix is A = c\,u v^\top, then (\Omega \circ A)_{ij}=\Omega_{ij}(c u_i v_j), so \Omega \circ A = c\,\mathrm{diag}(u)\,\Omega\,\mathrm{diag}(v). However, the rank-preservation part is only conditionally true. Left/right multiplication by diagonal matrices preserves rank only when those diagonals are invertible (all u_i and v_j nonzero), and c\neq 0. If any scaling entry is zero, rank can drop.
